fullText: Photograph: Courtesy Matthew Murphy | Stranger Things: The First ShadowReviewStranger Things: The First Shadow3 out of 5 starsA Netflix happening on Broadway.Theater, DramaMarquis Theatre, Midtown WestOpen runRecommendedTuesday April 22 2025ShareCopy LinkFacebookTwitterPinterestEmailWhatsAppBuy ticketWritten by Adam FeldmanTheater and Dance Editor, Time Out USAAdvertising window.rawSlots = window.rawSlots || []; window.rawSlots.push('{"adSlotId":"/5185/body1/event","adContainerId":"ad-body-1-46","isOutOfPage":false,"isRegistered":false,"adSizes":[{"viewport":[992,50],"slotSize":[]},{"viewport":[320,50],"slotSize":[[1,1],[320,100],[320,50],[300,600],[300,250],[300,100],[300,50]]},{"viewport":[0,0],"slotSize":[]}],"prebidSizes":[{"minViewPort":[800,0],"sizes":[[728,90]]},{"minViewPort":[320,50],"sizes":[[320,100],[320,50],[300,600],[300,250],[300,100],[300,50]]},{"minViewPort":[320,0],"sizes":[[320,100],[320,50],[300,250],[300,100],[300,50]]},{"minViewPort":[0,0],"sizes":[]}],"adTags":[{"key":"type","value":"body1"},{"key":"ad_slot_number","value":"ad-body-1"},{"key":"refresh","value":"30"}],"adSenseTags":[],"adSlotGroup":"body","breakpoints":["xs","sm"],"loadsAutomatically":true}'); Time Out saysBroadway review by Adam Feldman Stranger Things is happening. Nearly three years after plans were announced for a theatrical prequel to Netflix‚Äôs hit nostalgia-horror series, and 18 months after the debut of that prequel in London, the show has finally arrived on Broadway. While it calls itself The First Shadow, there‚Äôs nothing dark or stealthy about the massive production that is now possessing the Marquis Theatre, a second-floor hotel auditorium built Poltergeist-style on the graves of five old venues that were razed to make way for the Marriott. There‚Äôs something apt, inevitable even, about Stranger Things taking over this accursed space. Like it or not: It‚Äôs heeeee-eeeere. Directed by Stephen Daldry and co-directed by Justin Martin, Stranger Things announces its maximalist style from the outset with an eye-popping interdimensional disaster. It is 1943, and the U.S.S. Eldridge‚Äîyes, a J.K. Rowling‚Äìlevel pun on eldritch‚Äîis the subject of a secret experiment by a government outpost that I regret to inform you is named ‚ÄúProject Rainbow base Marquis.‚Äù The goal is to make the Eldridge invisible, but instead it moves to a different plane, as though tearing through a timespace map of the known world. Here be dragons, or rather demogorgons: slinky monsters with faces that open like carnivorous flowers. The ship‚Äôs captain stares into the Abyss, and the Abyss stares back. Stranger Things: The First Shadow | Photograph: Courtesy Evan Zimmerman When this cold open ends, a Stranger Things logo appears and we move to 1959 in Hawkins, Indiana, Broadway, population 33. The rialto‚Äôs only larger cast is in Harry Potter and the Cursed Child, this show's close cousin. Both are epic spinoffs of popular series on supernatural themes, set in different generations from the originals; both are presented by the trans-Atlantic megaproducer Sonia Friedman; both include illusions designed by Jamie Harrison. Harry Potter playwright Jack Thorne is even co-credited with shaping this play‚Äôs story alongside its overall author, Kate Trefry, and the Duffer Brothers, who created the TV series. Unlike Cursed Child, however‚Äîthe pre-Ozempic version, at least‚ÄîThe First Shadow doesn‚Äôt offer much by way of characters or plot beyond adding meager flesh to already familiar bones. And padding a skeleton doesn‚Äôt make it scarier, just bulkier. Stranger Things: The First Shadow | Photograph: Courtesy Matthew Murphy The central character of Trefly‚Äôs play is Henry Creel (Louis McCartney), a troubled teen who will grow up to become the franchise‚Äôs primary baddie but at this point is more like a boy Wednesday Addams: morbid and unsettling. Henry‚Äôs father (T.R. Knight) and mother (Rosie Benton) have relocated to Hawkins from Arizona‚Äîwhere, rumor has it, Henry blinded a neighbor‚Äîin hope of a new start. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm normal,‚Äù he repeats to himself, but he's not. All teenagers have demons, but his demons are real; they give him brutal powers and sometimes seem to control him. Henry is not on the spectrum, as he may initially seem, but he is an extension of Project Rainbow; his connections to the Eldridge, and those of the sadistic Dr. Martin Brenner (Alex Breaux), are the play‚Äôs most substantial contributions to Stranger Things lore. Stranger Things: The First Shadow | Photograph: Courtesy Matthew Murphy Imagining sympathetic back stories for bad guys is not a new trick: The literary originality of John Gardner‚Äôs Grendel and Gregory Maguire‚Äôs Wicked has already rusted into the Star Wars prequels and more recent villain‚Äôs-eye narratives (Maleficent, Joker, Ratched, Cruella). And the specifics of Henry‚Äôs arc are also not new: They correspond, if inexactly, to flashbacks from Season 4 of the TV series. In a genre that tends to draw on fear of the unknown, that doesn‚Äôt leave much room for suspense. Watching it, you can‚Äôt help knowing that by the time the TV timeline begins, Stranger Things will have happened. The play gives Henry a budding romance with Patty Newby (Gabrielle Nevaeh), who has been adopted by their school‚Äôs principal. They bond over their shared love for the Captain Midnight adventure serial and because both feel like social outcasts, though Henry is actually treated quite well by his classmates, and he and Patty are cast as the leads in the school play (which, by very silly coincidence, is The Dark of the Moon, a 1945 drama about a witch boy and the girl he loves). Patty doesn‚Äôt seem perturbed at all when he reveals his supernatural powers to her, which is one of many things that make you doubt that Stranger Things could happen in anything like a real world. But McCartney‚Äôs extraordinary presence draws you in all the same. It‚Äôs an intensely physical performance‚Äîat one point, the small and flexible actor jumps into a larger man‚Äôs arms like a chimp‚Äîbut also a magnetically focused and emotive one. He‚Äôs the production‚Äôs most special effect. Stranger Things: The First Shadow | Photograph: Courtesy Evan Zimmerman While the parts of the play that deal with Henry are evasive on the question of his free will‚Äîand oversentimental about a boy who tortures animals and murders people‚Äîthey are far more interesting than the rest. An inordinate amount of time is devoted to Henry‚Äôs peers, eight of whom are destined to become the parents of the four kids from Season 1. Joyce Maldonado (Alison Jaye) and two boys who inexplicably love her, Jim Hopper (Burke Swanson) and Bob Newby (Juan Carlos), don homemade Ghostbusters gear to investigate local misdoings in what amounts to a paranormal Scooby-Doo adventure. (Bob, who moonlights as a radio DJ: ‚ÄúAnother pet was found dead today, which brings the grand total to five pets in nine days. It‚Äôs got some wondering if something sinister is going on.‚Äù Wondering?) Stranger Things: The First Shadow | Photograph: Courtesy Matthew Murphy Unless you‚Äôre a franchise fanatic on the hunt for Easter eggs, the non-Creel material drags. But it may be wrong to judge Stranger Things as a play, exactly. In a way, it‚Äôs not far removed from other Netflix tie-ins like Squid Game: The Experience or The Queen's Ball: A Bridgerton Experience. When Daldry and Martin bring the show's best elements together‚ÄîMcCartney‚Äôs acting, Miriam Buether‚Äôs sets, Brigitte Reiffenstuel‚Äôs costumes, Jon Clark‚Äôs lighting, Paul Arditti‚Äôs sound, the production group 59‚Äôs video design and effects‚Äîthe production is like a breathtaking theme-park ride. And as with a roller coaster, there are longueurs as the show chugs up to where it needs to be to deliver the next big whoop. Go and enjoy, but don‚Äôt be surprised if you soon forget that Stranger Things has happened. Stranger Things: The First Shadow. Marquis Theatre (Broadway). By Kate Trefry. Story by the Duffer Brothers, Jack Thorne and Trefry. Directed by Stephen Daldry. Co-directed by Justin Martin. With Louis McCartney, T.R. Knight, Rosie Benton, Alex Breaux, Gabrielle Nevaeh, Alison Jaye, Juan Carlos, Burke Swanson, Andrew Hovelson. Running time: 2hrs 40mins. One intermission. Follow Adam Feldman on X: @FeldmanAdamFollow Adam Feldman on Bluesky: @FeldmanAdamFollow Adam Feldman on Threads: @adfeldmanFollow Time Out Theater on X: @TimeOutTheaterKeep up with the latest news and reviews on our Time Out Theater Facebook page Stranger Things: The First Shadow | Photograph: Courtesy Evan ZimmermanDetailsEvent website:broadway.strangerthingsonstage.comAddressMarquis Theatre210 W 46th StNew York10036Cross street:at BroadwayTransport:Subway: A, C, E to 42nd St‚ÄìPort Authority; dtliExcerpt: ne in the series‚Äîmade his ominous appearance at the close of the first act, I fantasized about pulling him aside to ask for a sedative. Although in truth the show itself was already soporific enough. Adam Feldman, Time Out New York: When Daldry and Martin bring the show's best elements together‚ÄîMcCartney‚Äôs acting, Miriam Buether‚Äôs sets, Brigitte Reiffenstuel‚Äôs costumes, Jon Clark‚Äôs lighting, Paul Arditti‚Äôs sound, the production group 59‚Äôs video design and effects‚Äîthe production is like a breathtaking theme-park ride. And as with a roller coaster, there are longueurs as the show chugs up to where it needs to be to deliver the next big whoop. Go and enjoy, but don‚Äôt be surprised if you soon forget that Stranger Things has happened. Matt Windman, amNY: A three-hour fan wiki brought to life, complete with origin stories, stilted dialogue, lame jokes, and sequences seemingly constructed only to set up the next visual effect. David Finkle, New York Stage Review: Whatever of this makes sense

keyPhrases.quote: doesn't offer much by way of characters or plot
adding meager flesh to already familiar bones
padding a skeleton doesn't make it scarier, just bulkier

llmScore.reasoning: Claude: The review harshly criticizes the fundamental elements of story and character development, using dismissive metaphors that suggest the show fails to improve upon its source material. | GPT-4o-mini: The review is predominantly negative, criticizing the lack of character and plot development, leading to a clear recommendation against seeing the show.

showScoreExcerpt: ‚Äú ‚ÄòThe First Shadow‚Äô suffers from dramatic bloat and tonal inconsistency. The biggest frustration with it is the sense that it might have been show of the year with 30 minutes of really ruthless cuts...It‚Äôs not perfect, but it‚Äôs as close to the Upside Down as you‚Äôre going to get without having your head bitten off by a demogorgon.‚Äù
